Award.AwardTitle: Fourier Coefficients, L-functions, and Endoscopy Correspondences of Automorphic Forms
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI, Dihua Jiang, has been working on some basic problems related to Automorphic L-functions and explicit Langlands functorial transfers for square-integrable automorphic forms. He investigates the basic structures of the discrete spectrum of automorphic forms and the related problems on the Langlands functoriality. In the local theory, his research attacks the local Langlands conjectures and related basic problems in harmonic analysis of p-adic groups. His long term goal is to understand the general local-global-automorphic principles in the theory of automorphic forms, which reflects one of the basic principles in the arithmetic and number theory.

The PI, Dihua Jiang, is an expert in the modern theory of automorphic forms and the Langlands Program. Automorphic forms are functions with abundant symmetries. These symmetries are the guidelines to understand the intrinsic structures of objects in our universe. In Mathematics, these symmetries are common grounds for many different theories such as Geometry, Number Theory, Mathematical Physics, Algebra and Analysis. Hence the modern theory of automorphic forms, essentially the Langlands program, provides the organizing principle for further research in these areas. The research of Dihua Jiang establishes basic structures for automorphic forms and hence
yields essential contribution to the Langlands program.

The Intellectual Merit of the Proposed Activity:

The Principal Investigator (PI), Dihua Jiang, has been working on basic problems on automorphic forms and the Langlands Program. 

Automorphic forms are functions with abundant symmetries. These symmetries are the guidelines to understand the intrinsic structures of objects in our universe. In Mathematics, these symmetries are common grounds for many different theories such as Geometry, Number Theory, Mathematical Physics, Algebra and Analysis. Hence the modern theory of automorphic forms, essentially the Langlands program, provides the organizing principle for further research in these areas. The research of
Dihua Jiang establishes basic structures for automorphic forms and hence 
yields essential contribution to the Langlands program.  

One of the main problems in the modern theory of automorphic forms is to understand the discrete spectrum of the space of square-integrable automorphic functions. The  theory of Endoscopy, whose existence was discovered by R. Langlands in 1980's and confirmed through the fundamental work of B.-C. Ngo and J. Arthur and others via the trace formula approach. The PI intends to construct explicit modules for the cuspidal automorphic forms and construct via integral transform with automorphic kernel functions. Meanwhile, he also develops the local theory, relating basic problems in harmonic analysis of p-adic groups. His long term goal is to understand the general local-global-automorphic principles in the theory of automorphic forms, which reflects one of the basic principles in the arithmetic and number theory.

In the global theory, the PI developed the framework relating the theory of endoscopy to the structures of Fourier coefficients of automorphic forms, and to poles and special values of their automorphic$L$-functions. From this general framework, the PI is able to construct explicit modules for cuspidal automorphic representations of classical groups, which yields special types of general Langlands functorial transfers for square-integrable automorphic forms and explicit formulas for residues or special values of automorphic $L$-functions, and prove the global Gan-Gross-Prasadconjecture for classical groups.
In the local theory, his research attacks the local Langlands conjectures, the Jacquet conjecture on the local converse theorem, and relevant basic problems in harmonic analysisof p-adic groups. 


 The Broader Impacts Resulting from the Proposed Activity:

The research activities of Jiang include his collaboration withD. Ginzburg and D. Soudry in Israel, Y.-J. Qin and C.-Y. Wu in Shanghai, C.-F. Nien in Taiwan,B.-Y. Sun in Beijing, L. Zhang and C.-B. Zhu in Singapore, B.-Y. Liu at IAS, Princeton, and G. Savin in Utah, and S. Stevens in UK.He has four students graduated with PhD., who lead to successful career in Math. Currently, he has four graduate studentsin Minneapolis and meanwhile, he supervises undergraduates of CLA math major for their senior theses.Jiang actively participates international and national conferences andresearch programs in his area and gives series of lectures in various Summer Graduate Schools.He was an editor for Journal of Algebra, a reviewer or panelist for AMS, NSF, NSA, Israeli Science Foundation,Chinese Academy of Sciences, Gobierno de Chile, Research Grants Council of Hong Kong, Ministry of Education in Taiwan, and Swiss NationalScience Foundation;a co-PI of US-Israeli binational grant (BSF).He was also a co-organizer of many international research conferences, including the NSF supported the Memorial Conference at Yale for Piatetski-Shapiro in 2012, an AIM workshop in 2015, and Paul J. Sally, Jr. Midwest Representation Theory Conference 2015 and 2016. 

The PI also trained successfully graduate students and postdocs.
